articles.title: Google’s Direct Answers Now Shown on 10% of SERPs
articles.description: In a return to Google’s more direct answers search results format, 10% of mobile SERPs now show a direct answer box. The statistic represents a 1.4% increase of direct answers in April as compared to March. This month-over-month increase is one of the greatest on record, according to data from RankRanger’s most recent report on US-based mobile SERP features. Such data is noteworthy, because it seems to demonstrate that Google is increasing its efforts to produce more immediate answers to user queries.

articles.title: Google Officially Rolls Out ‘More Results’ Search Button On Mobile
articles.description: Last month, Google announced on Twitter that it had officially launched its “More results” button for additional search results on mobile devices. Google had been testing this feature as a replacement for the “Next” button that previously displayed a new page of mobile search results.

articles.title: Google Chrome to Prevent Videos With Sound from Autoplaying
articles.description: Most videos with sound will be disabled automatically in Google’s latest version of Chrome for desktop. There will, however, be exceptions for videos that Google thinks individual users are interested in. This is determined by three factors, one of which is whether the user has viewed the video before. Google is taking the same step with video ads on its desktop and mobile browsers. Videos that are designed to autoplay without sound remain unaffected.

articles.title: Google Search Console is Notifying Site Owners About AMP Issues
articles.description: Google Search Console has been sending email notifications to site owners regarding social media content on AMP pages. While these issues do not affect how web pages show up in search results, they may affect user experience, which Google considers an indirect ranking factor. Site owners should take advantage of Google Search Console’s email notifications to quickly address social media issues on AMP pages and ensure an optimal user experience.

articles.title: Google Expanding Types of Predictions They Remove from Autocomplete
articles.description: Google search liaison Danny Sullivan announced that Google will be expanding the types of autocomplete predictions it prohibits. Over the years, autocomplete predictions have induced public outrage over alleged racism or political party bias. While Google has steadfastly maintained that its autocomplete results merely reflect the behavior of its search users, the company will nevertheless be removing inappropriate predictions that “are reasonably perceived as hateful or prejudiced toward individuals and groups” regardless of whether the individuals or groups fall within a protected class.
